<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">New polymeric structures together with spectroscopic properties of the Eu–CDTA system are presented.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Two crystal structures of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> complexes with CDTA (<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-tetraacetate), [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>[Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CDTA)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>) and [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Eu(CDTA)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.375H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>), are presented. Both structures are polymeric and the central metal ions are eight-coordinate. The first coordination sphere of each Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> cation contains five carboxylate oxygen atoms, two nitrogen ones and a water molecule. elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

New polymeric structures together with spectroscopic properties of the Eu-CDTA system are presented.

Abstract

Two crystal structures of EuIII complexes with CDTA (trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetate), [C(NH2)3]3[Eu2(CDTA)2(H2O)2]ClO4 ⋅7H2O (I) and [C(NH2)3][Eu(CDTA)(H2O)]⋅2.375H2O (II), are presented. Both structures are polymeric and the central metal ions are eight-coordinate. The first coordination sphere of each EuIII cation contains five carboxylate oxygen atoms, two nitrogen ones and a water molecule. For I, as well as for water solutions of the EuIII-CDTA complex at various pH values, the spectroscopic (UV-Vis) properties were investigated.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Lanthanide polyaminopolycarboxylate chelates play an important role both in fundamental investigations and in several areas of practical applications. They are used, among others, as shift reagents in NMR spectroscopy , contrast agents in MRI imaging , structural probes  and luminescent tags in immunoassays . This family of compounds has been epitomized by complexes of Ln<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> with the ethylenediaminetetraacetate (EDTA) anion, which have been extensively studied both in solution e.g.  and in the solid state e.g.  and now may serve as a kind of standard when the structure, spectroscopic and/or thermodynamic properties of lanthanide polyaminopolycarboxylates are discussed. It is therefore of interest to find how the properties are altered when the EDTA<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> skeleton is modified. In this work we present a study of two Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> complexes with such a ligand, i.e. <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-tetraacetate (CDTA). The investigations of Ln<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–CDTA complexes carried out so far have been focused to a great part on their properties in aqueous solutions and included thermodynamic as well as spectroscopic aspects. Their stability constants are higher by an order or two of magnitude, depending on the lanthanide, than those of the EDTA complexes , and generally saying, they are thermodynamically stable . The spectroscopic studies have revealed that in solutions of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–CDTA complexes an equilibrium exists between two different species, nine- and eight-coordinate, the dissimilarity between them consisting of a different number of coordinated water molecules (three or two) . The average number of these molecules has been found to be 2.3–2.6 and is a little lower than that found in water solutions of the EDTA complexes (2.6–2.8) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Lanthanide polyaminopolycarboxylate chelates play an important role both in fundamental investigations and in several areas of practical applications. They are used, among others, as shift reagents in NMR spectroscopy , contrast agents in MRI imaging , structural probes  and luminescent tags in immunoassays . This family of compounds has been epitomized by complexes of LnIII with the ethylenediaminetetraacetate (EDTA) anion, which have been extensively studied both in solution e.g.  and in the solid state e.g.  and now may serve as a kind of standard when the structure, spectroscopic and/or thermodynamic properties of lanthanide polyaminopolycarboxylates are discussed. It is therefore of interest to find how the properties are altered when the EDTA4- skeleton is modified. In this work we present a study of two EuIII complexes with such a ligand, i.e. trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetate (CDTA). The investigations of LnIII-CDTA complexes carried out so far have been focused to a great part on their properties in aqueous solutions and included thermodynamic as well as spectroscopic aspects. Their stability constants are higher by an order or two of magnitude, depending on the lanthanide, than those of the EDTA complexes , and generally saying, they are thermodynamically stable . The spectroscopic studies have revealed that in solutions of EuIII-CDTA complexes an equilibrium exists between two different species, nine- and eight-coordinate, the dissimilarity between them consisting of a different number of coordinated water molecules (three or two) . The average number of these molecules has been found to be 2.3-2.6 and is a little lower than that found in water solutions of the EDTA complexes (2.6-2.8) .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Because of difficulties connected with growing of monocrystals of adequate quality, structural data for Ln<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–CDTA complexes are scarce. To the best of the authors’ knowledge only three crystal structures of these complexes have been published. Two of them, NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[Ln(CDTA)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>, Ho<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>), are monomeric and isostructural  whereas in the third one, Na[Eu(CDTA)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , dimeric anions of [Eu(CDTA)–μ-(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–Eu(CDTA)]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> are formed. For the last system luminescence properties were also reported. In all these complexes the Ln<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ions are eight-coordinate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Because of difficulties connected with growing of monocrystals of adequate quality, structural data for LnIII-CDTA complexes are scarce. To the best of the authors' knowledge only three crystal structures of these complexes have been published. Two of them, NH4[Ln(CDTA)(H2O)2]⋅4.5H2O (Ln=GdIII, HoIII), are monomeric and isostructural  whereas in the third one, Na[Eu(CDTA)(H2O)]⋅4H2O , dimeric anions of [Eu(CDTA)-μ-(H2O)2-Eu(CDTA)]2- are formed. For the last system luminescence properties were also reported. In all these complexes the LnIII ions are eight-coordinate.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the crystal, the coordination surrounding of Ln<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ion is unambiguously defined, therefore the spectra of the crystals may be a good starting point for interpretation of spectral data of solution systems. The paucity of such data has motivated us to attempt the preparation of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–CDTA complexes in the crystalline state, to study their crystal structures and spectroscopic properties and to compare the latter with the analogous properties of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–CDTA complexes in solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the crystal, the coordination surrounding of LnIII ion is unambiguously defined, therefore the spectra of the crystals may be a good starting point for interpretation of spectral data of solution systems. The paucity of such data has motivated us to attempt the preparation of EuIII-CDTA complexes in the crystalline state, to study their crystal structures and spectroscopic properties and to compare the latter with the analogous properties of EuIII-CDTA complexes in solution.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

Solutions for spectroscopic measurements: A stock solution of europium chloride was prepared by dissolving Eu2O3 (99.99%; Standford materials) in 2moldm-3 hydrochloric acid. The EuIII ion concentration was determined complexometrically using xylenol orange as an indicator. The stock solution of H4CDTA (98%; Lancaster) was prepared by half-neutralization with NaOH. The pH of the 1:1.1 EuIII-CDTA solutions was adjusted by a carbonate-free NaOH water solution.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Crystal preparations: An aqueous solution of equimolar quantities of europium perchlorate and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>CDTA was heated at ca. 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Next, solid [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was added until the pH value was 5. Large colourless crystals of [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>[Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CDTA)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>) were formed during slow evaporation. The other crystals, [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Eu(CDTA)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.375H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>), were obtained as follows: a suspension of Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>CDTA was heated at ca. 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. After dissolution of the substrates, the solution was alkalized with [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> to a final pH value of 3, and left for crystallization.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Crystal preparations: An aqueous solution of equimolar quantities of europium perchlorate and H4CDTA was heated at ca. 80°C. Next, solid [C(NH2)3]2CO3 was added until the pH value was 5. Large colourless crystals of [C(NH2)3]3[Eu2(CDTA)2(H2O)2]ClO4 ⋅7H2O (I) were formed during slow evaporation. The other crystals, [C(NH2)3][Eu(CDTA)(H2O)]⋅2.375H2O (II), were obtained as follows: a suspension of Eu2O3 and H4CDTA was heated at ca. 80°C. After dissolution of the substrates, the solution was alkalized with [C(NH2)3]2CO3 to a final pH value of 3, and left for crystallization.

<ce:section-title>X-ray study</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Appropriate crystals were cut from larger ones and mounted on a Kuma KM4 diffractometer equipped with a CCD counter. The collected data were corrected for polarization, Lorentz and absorption, the last calculated from the crystal habit captured from photo scans. Both crystals turned out to be twinned. The twinning of crystal <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> was pseudo-merohedral; this was brought about by the fact that the unit cells spanned by vectors <ce:bold>a</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>b</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>c</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>a</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>a</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>b</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>a</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>c</ce:bold> have very similar lattice constants. The fraction of the first twin component found from the refinement was 0.676(1). The twinning matrix in <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> was (−1/2 −1/2 0/ −3/2 1/2 0/ −1/2 1/2 −1) with the result that only reflections with <ce:italic>h</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>k</ce:italic> even overlapped. The structure of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> was solved and refined against all reflections, while that of <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> was solved using one twin component and refined against both. The positions of Eu were found from Patterson maps, the rest of the non-H atoms from difference Fourier maps. The positions of the C- and N-bonded hydrogen atoms were calculated geometrically. The refinement was full-matrix with all ordered non-H atoms anisotropic. The oxygen atoms from disordered water molecules (in <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>) were refined isotropically and C- and N-bonded H atoms were constrained to 1.2 times the factors of the relevant C atoms. Because of twinning and partial overlapping of some reflections the precision of the structure determination of <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> unfortunately deteriorated. Our several attempts to find an untwinned sample failed and therefore we decided to solve and refine the structure against the twin data. The large volume of the asymmetric part seems upsetting. However we could not find a cell with smaller volume and herein we present the best model of twinning and the crystal structure which we have been able to find. Both structures were solved and refined by <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>97  and <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>97 , respectively, and the program <ce:small-caps>diamond</ce:small-caps>
 was used for the molecular graphics. The data concerning the crystal parameters, data collection and refinement details are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray study

Appropriate crystals were cut from larger ones and mounted on a Kuma KM4 diffractometer equipped with a CCD counter. The collected data were corrected for polarization, Lorentz and absorption, the last calculated from the crystal habit captured from photo scans. Both crystals turned out to be twinned. The twinning of crystal I was pseudo-merohedral; this was brought about by the fact that the unit cells spanned by vectors a, b, c, and a, a-b, a-c have very similar lattice constants. The fraction of the first twin component found from the refinement was 0.676(1). The twinning matrix in II was (-1/2 -1/2 0/ -3/2 1/2 0/ -1/2 1/2 -1) with the result that only reflections with h + k even overlapped. The structure of I was solved and refined against all reflections, while that of II was solved using one twin component and refined against both. The positions of Eu were found from Patterson maps, the rest of the non-H atoms from difference Fourier maps. The positions of the C- and N-bonded hydrogen atoms were calculated geometrically. The refinement was full-matrix with all ordered non-H atoms anisotropic. The oxygen atoms from disordered water molecules (in II) were refined isotropically and C- and N-bonded H atoms were constrained to 1.2 times the factors of the relevant C atoms. Because of twinning and partial overlapping of some reflections the precision of the structure determination of II unfortunately deteriorated. Our several attempts to find an untwinned sample failed and therefore we decided to solve and refine the structure against the twin data. The large volume of the asymmetric part seems upsetting. However we could not find a cell with smaller volume and herein we present the best model of twinning and the crystal structure which we have been able to find. Both structures were solved and refined by shelxs97  and shelxl97 , respectively, and the program diamond  was used for the molecular graphics. The data concerning the crystal parameters, data collection and refinement details are presented in  .

elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopy

UV-Vis measurements

Electronic absorption spectra were recorded on a Cary 500 UV-Vis-near-IR spectrophotometer. The solutions were measured at room temperature. Only spectra of I were recorded because we could not obtain a good sample of II. The absorption spectra of I were measured at 293 and 30K (in an Oxford CF 1204 continuous flow helium cryostat). The oscillator strengths (P) were determined using the equation:   P = 4.32 ×   10   - 9   ( cd   )   - 1   ∫ A ( σ )  d σ   where c is the concentration of the EuIII ion in M, d is the length of the optical way in cm and A(σ) is the absorbance as the function of the wavenumber in cm-1. The P values were not corrected for the population of the 7F1 state at room temperature. Corrected emission spectra were measured on a SLM Aminco 500 spectrofluorometer at 293 and 77K. For luminescence, the EuIII ion was excited with a wavelength of 394nm.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Structure</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Both structures are built up from polymeric complex chains, guanidinium cations, water of crystallization (partially disordered in <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>), and, in the case of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, also perchlorate anions. The polymeric chains are composed of europium cations, <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-tetraacetate (CDTA) anions and water molecules coordinated to europium. Each polymer unit (mer) contains a Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> cation and a CDTA anion which is coordinated to the metal through its four carboxylate oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms, filling thus six coordinate sites. The seventh site is occupied by a water molecule. Apart from that each mer donates one of its carboxylate oxygen atoms to the first coordination sphere of an Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ion in a neighbouring mer (accepting at the same time an analogous O atom from the other neighbour). In this way infinite polymeric chains are formed and the europium cations are eight-coordinate. In <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> there are two symmetry independent Eu sites, and accordingly two different mers. In <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> the number of symmetry independent Eu sites is 4. Nevertheless, superimposition of all six mers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>) shows that their conformations are very similar, the difference being only in small variations of bond lengths and angles. The Eu–O and Eu–N distances (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>) are similar to those found in the europium dimeric complex with CDTA, Na[Eu(CDTA)H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , however the Eu–OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> bond distances are significantly longer in the present structures. The Eu–OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> average distances are 0.125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (compound <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>) and 0.103<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (compound <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>) longer than in the quoted dimer. These variations may be caused by different modes of interaction of guanidinium and sodium cations with the CDTA moiety, because these cations induce different hydrogen bond networks. In both presented structures the shortest bonds are those involving carboxylate O atoms, the Eu–OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ones are longer, and the Eu–N ones are the longest. As far as the conformation of the ligand is concerned, two subsets of methylenecarboxylate groups may be discerned. In each CDTA ligand two such groups are almost parallel. In <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> the angles between the least-squares fitted planes of such planes (namely C13 and C23, C33 and C43, C51 and C63, C71 and C83; the methylenecarboxylate groups are labelled after their central C atoms) are in the range 0.6–10.0°. In <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> the relevant angles differ more: the planes of the groups C1 and C12 are mutually twisted by 21.0°, whereas the groups C21 and C34 are twisted by only 4.5°. The other pairs are twisted by 54.9° and 59.7° in <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, and 60.1–70.5° in <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>. Apart from that it may be noticed that the C–O bonds are generally longer when the O atom is coordinated to Eu, although the difference between the C–O lengths with O atoms coordinated and uncoordinated falls often within the range of experimental error. The approximate symmetry of all Eu first coordination spheres in both structures is C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (after neglecting the difference between the water and the bridging carboxylate O atoms); the axis passes through the center of the cyclohexyl ring, Eu and the bisector of the relevant water–Eu–bridging O atom angle. It is noteworthy that in the presented crystals the CDTA ligand behaves in a way different to that of its analogue, i.e. ethylenediaminetetracetate (EDTA). The Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–EDTA complexes are monomeric, and the europium cation is nine-coordinate , contrary to the polymeric structures with eight-coordinate Eu ions in the present structures. Fragments of the polymeric complex chains are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure

Both structures are built up from polymeric complex chains, guanidinium cations, water of crystallization (partially disordered in II), and, in the case of I, also perchlorate anions. The polymeric chains are composed of europium cations, trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetate (CDTA) anions and water molecules coordinated to europium. Each polymer unit (mer) contains a EuIII cation and a CDTA anion which is coordinated to the metal through its four carboxylate oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms, filling thus six coordinate sites. The seventh site is occupied by a water molecule. Apart from that each mer donates one of its carboxylate oxygen atoms to the first coordination sphere of an EuIII ion in a neighbouring mer (accepting at the same time an analogous O atom from the other neighbour). In this way infinite polymeric chains are formed and the europium cations are eight-coordinate. In I there are two symmetry independent Eu sites, and accordingly two different mers. In II the number of symmetry independent Eu sites is 4. Nevertheless, superimposition of all six mers ( ) shows that their conformations are very similar, the difference being only in small variations of bond lengths and angles. The Eu-O and Eu-N distances (see  ) are similar to those found in the europium dimeric complex with CDTA, Na[Eu(CDTA)H2O]⋅4H2O , however the Eu-OH2 bond distances are significantly longer in the present structures. The Eu-OH2 average distances are 0.125Å (compound I) and 0.103Å (compound II) longer than in the quoted dimer. These variations may be caused by different modes of interaction of guanidinium and sodium cations with the CDTA moiety, because these cations induce different hydrogen bond networks. In both presented structures the shortest bonds are those involving carboxylate O atoms, the Eu-OH2 ones are longer, and the Eu-N ones are the longest. As far as the conformation of the ligand is concerned, two subsets of methylenecarboxylate groups may be discerned. In each CDTA ligand two such groups are almost parallel. In II the angles between the least-squares fitted planes of such planes (namely C13 and C23, C33 and C43, C51 and C63, C71 and C83; the methylenecarboxylate groups are labelled after their central C atoms) are in the range 0.6-10.0°. In I the relevant angles differ more: the planes of the groups C1 and C12 are mutually twisted by 21.0°, whereas the groups C21 and C34 are twisted by only 4.5°. The other pairs are twisted by 54.9° and 59.7° in I, and 60.1-70.5° in II. Apart from that it may be noticed that the C-O bonds are generally longer when the O atom is coordinated to Eu, although the difference between the C-O lengths with O atoms coordinated and uncoordinated falls often within the range of experimental error. The approximate symmetry of all Eu first coordination spheres in both structures is C2 (after neglecting the difference between the water and the bridging carboxylate O atoms); the axis passes through the center of the cyclohexyl ring, Eu and the bisector of the relevant water-Eu-bridging O atom angle. It is noteworthy that in the presented crystals the CDTA ligand behaves in a way different to that of its analogue, i.e. ethylenediaminetetracetate (EDTA). The EuIII-EDTA complexes are monomeric, and the europium cation is nine-coordinate , contrary to the polymeric structures with eight-coordinate Eu ions in the present structures. Fragments of the polymeric complex chains are presented in   .

elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic results

For the 7F0 → 5D0 transition in I we were able to observe one peak at 17245cm-1 at room temperature while at 30K two components at 17241 and 17234cm-1 appeared. The ground (7F0) and emitting (5D0) states of the europium ion are non-degenerate, therefore the number of peaks observed in the range 578-582nm indicates the number of various chemical surroundings of the EuIII ion. Accordingly we may assume existence of two different europium sites at 30K and of one site at room temperature. In the absorption spectrum of a related compound, [C(NH2)3][Eu(EDTA)(H2O)3], only one 7F0 → 5D0 peak was observed at a very similar energy, 17252cm-1 at room temperature  and 17243cm-1 at 77K. Also in the 7F0 → 5D1 and 7F0 → 5D2 transitions the number of components in the spectrum recorded at 77K is greater than that found in the spectrum taken at 293K. For the low local symmetry of the EuIII ion in each symmetry independent site the number of the components should be 3 and 5, respectively. At room temperature the number of crystal field levels in the absorption spectrum for 7F0 → 5D1 and 7F0 → 5D2 are actually 3 and 5, whereas in the low temperature (30K) transitions 5 and 7 crystal field components in the range 19050-19120 and 21390-21550cm-1, respectively, may be seen ( ). This may suggest that between 293 and 100K (taking into account the structural data reported above) a phase transition occurs. The oscillator strengths found in I at 293 and 30K are presented in  . Inspection of these data reveals somewhat anomalous behaviour of these quantities. Namely, the intensities of all the presented transitions increase on lowering the temperature. Such a change might be attributed to a phase transition in the case of 7F0 → 5D0 and 7F0 → 5D2. The most surprising thing is, however, the anomalous growth of the intensity of the 7F0 → 5D1 transition, which is more than twice as intense as theoretically predicted . Such an increase cannot be explained by thermal population of the 7F1 state, which would account only for the loss of approximately 20 % of the intensity at room temperature. The reasons for this phenomenon are unclear, and perhaps need more detailed investigations, which however lie outside the scope of the present paper.

At room temperature the transition 5D0 → 7F0 was unsplit, whereas the 5D0 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F2 transitions had 3 and 4 discernible components. At 77K the number of observed components was 2 for 5D0 → 7F0, 6 for 5D0 → 7F1 and 7 for 5D0 → 7F2.

<ce:para view="all">The results presented above may serve as a background for the interpretation of the spectroscopic properties of water solutions of the Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–CDTA system. These properties remain essentially the same in the pH range between 3.5 and 9. The most significant changes in the absorption spectra are observed above pH 10. In  the absorption spectra of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–CDTA solutions at pH 7.40 and 11.0 have been juxtaposed. For both solutions two maxima at 17<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>250 and 17<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>239<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> may be observed for the <ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>

These values are similar both to the maximum found in the crystal at room temperature and to the analogous maxima found in solutions of the Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–EDTA complex (17<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>254 and 17<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) . There is another similarity that perhaps should be mentioned. Namely, the most intense crystal field components in the <ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>

<ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> transition in both solutions very closely match the analogous components in the spectrum of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> at room temperature.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The results presented above may serve as a background for the interpretation of the spectroscopic properties of water solutions of the EuIII-CDTA system. These properties remain essentially the same in the pH range between 3.5 and 9. The most significant changes in the absorption spectra are observed above pH 10. In  the absorption spectra of EuIII-CDTA solutions at pH 7.40 and 11.0 have been juxtaposed. For both solutions two maxima at 17250 and 17239cm-1 may be observed for the 7F0 → 5D0 transition, which confirms the equilibrium of nine- and eight-coordinate isomers, as was previously reported at pH=6.0 . These values are similar both to the maximum found in the crystal at room temperature and to the analogous maxima found in solutions of the EuIII-EDTA complex (17254 and 17240cm-1) . There is another similarity that perhaps should be mentioned. Namely, the most intense crystal field components in the 7F0 → 5D2 transition in both solutions very closely match the analogous components in the spectrum of I at room temperature.

<ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> transition is, out of the three presented ones, the most affected by changes in the europium ion first coordination sphere. The oscillator strength of this band, like that of <ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>

<ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>, does not change essentially up to pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>≈<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9, and then, contrary to the latter transition, doubles at pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11. The <ce:italic>P</ce:italic> values for the solutions are greater than in <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, because of molecular dynamics around the metal ion in solutions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The most remarkable changes may be observed in the values of the oscillator strengths (). The P value of the transition 7F0 → 5D0 remains practically constant up to approximately pH=9 and then decreases by about half, reaching a value very similar to that calculated for I at room temperature. The magnetic-dipole allowed transition 7F0 → 5D1 in the solutions and in I at 293 K is constant with the P value close to the theoretical value . The intensity of the hypersensitive7F0 → 5D2 transition is, out of the three presented ones, the most affected by changes in the europium ion first coordination sphere. The oscillator strength of this band, like that of 7F0 → 5D0, does not change essentially up to pH~9, and then, contrary to the latter transition, doubles at pH=11. These changes may reflect the alterations within the first coordination sphere of the EuIII ion, consisting of partial substitution of coordinated water molecules by hydroxy anions  and/or formation of a polymeric species . The P values for the solutions are greater than in I at 293K, because of molecular dynamics around the metal ion in solutions.

<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The presented results suggest that the CDTA anion behaves in a somewhat different way in comparison to EDTA as far as the structural aspects are concerned. Namely CDTA shows a more pronounced tendency to form polymeric structures with lanthanides. Apart from that the coordination numbers of all Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–CDTA complexes are eight while in all known crystal structures of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–EDTA systems the Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> ion is nine-coordinate. The spectroscopic properties of the presented Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–CDTA systems in water solutions rather closely resemble those of related Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–EDTA ones. For instance for Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> complexes with both ligands the <ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0,1,2</ce:inf> transitions lie at very similar energies. The [Eu(CDTA)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3 or 2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> species remain stable up to pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>≈<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9, then partial hydrolysis and/or polymerization take place. The spectra of [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>[Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CDTA)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O at various temperatures reveal a phase transition in the crystal.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The presented results suggest that the CDTA anion behaves in a somewhat different way in comparison to EDTA as far as the structural aspects are concerned. Namely CDTA shows a more pronounced tendency to form polymeric structures with lanthanides. Apart from that the coordination numbers of all EuIII-CDTA complexes are eight while in all known crystal structures of EuIII-EDTA systems the EuIII ion is nine-coordinate. The spectroscopic properties of the presented EuIII-CDTA systems in water solutions rather closely resemble those of related EuIII-EDTA ones. For instance for EuIII complexes with both ligands the 7F0 → 5D0,1,2 transitions lie at very similar energies. The [Eu(CDTA)(H2O)3 or 2]- species remain stable up to pH~9, then partial hydrolysis and/or polymerization take place. The spectra of [C(NH2)3]3[Eu2(CDTA)2(H2O)2]ClO4 ⋅7H2O at various temperatures reveal a phase transition in the crystal.

<ce:para view="all">Crystal preparations: An aqueous solution of equimolar quantities of europium perchlorate and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>CDTA was heated at ca. 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Next, solid [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was added until the pH value was 5. Large colourless crystals of [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>[Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CDTA)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>I</ce:bold>) were formed during slow evaporation. The other crystals, [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Eu(CDTA)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.375H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>II</ce:bold>), were obtained as follows: a suspension of Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>CDTA was heated at ca. 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. After dissolution of the substrates, the solution was alkalized with [C(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> to a final pH value of 3, and left for crystallization.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Crystal preparations: An aqueous solution of equimolar quantities of europium perchlorate and H4CDTA was heated at ca. 80°C. Next, solid [C(NH2)3]2CO3 was added until the pH value was 5. Large colourless crystals of [C(NH2)3]3[Eu2(CDTA)2(H2O)2]ClO4 ⋅7H2O (I) were formed during slow evaporation. The other crystals, [C(NH2)3][Eu(CDTA)(H2O)]⋅2.375H2O (II), were obtained as follows: a suspension of Eu2O3 and H4CDTA was heated at ca. 80°C. After dissolution of the substrates, the solution was alkalized with [C(NH2)3]2CO3 to a final pH value of 3, and left for crystallization.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic results

For the 7F0 → 5D0 transition in I we were able to observe one peak at 17245cm-1 at room temperature while at 30K two components at 17241 and 17234cm-1 appeared. The ground (7F0) and emitting (5D0) states of the europium ion are non-degenerate, therefore the number of peaks observed in the range 578-582nm indicates the number of various chemical surroundings of the EuIII ion. Accordingly we may assume existence of two different europium sites at 30K and of one site at room temperature. In the absorption spectrum of a related compound, [C(NH2)3][Eu(EDTA)(H2O)3], only one 7F0 → 5D0 peak was observed at a very similar energy, 17252cm-1 at room temperature  and 17243cm-1 at 77K. Also in the 7F0 → 5D1 and 7F0 → 5D2 transitions the number of components in the spectrum recorded at 77K is greater than that found in the spectrum taken at 293K. For the low local symmetry of the EuIII ion in each symmetry independent site the number of the components should be 3 and 5, respectively. At room temperature the number of crystal field levels in the absorption spectrum for 7F0 → 5D1 and 7F0 → 5D2 are actually 3 and 5, whereas in the low temperature (30K) transitions 5 and 7 crystal field components in the range 19050-19120 and 21390-21550cm-1, respectively, may be seen ( ). This may suggest that between 293 and 100K (taking into account the structural data reported above) a phase transition occurs. The oscillator strengths found in I at 293 and 30K are presented in  . Inspection of these data reveals somewhat anomalous behaviour of these quantities. Namely, the intensities of all the presented transitions increase on lowering the temperature. Such a change might be attributed to a phase transition in the case of 7F0 → 5D0 and 7F0 → 5D2. The most surprising thing is, however, the anomalous growth of the intensity of the 7F0 → 5D1 transition, which is more than twice as intense as theoretically predicted . Such an increase cannot be explained by thermal population of the 7F1 state, which would account only for the loss of approximately 20 % of the intensity at room temperature. The reasons for this phenomenon are unclear, and perhaps need more detailed investigations, which however lie outside the scope of the present paper.

The splitting of the bands may also be observed in emission spectra at 77K. At room temperature the transition 5D0 → 7F0 was unsplit, whereas the 5D0 → 7F1 and 5D0 → 7F2 transitions had 3 and 4 discernible components. At 77K the number of observed components was 2 for 5D0 → 7F0, 6 for 5D0 → 7F1 and 7 for 5D0 → 7F2.

The results presented above may serve as a background for the interpretation of the spectroscopic properties of water solutions of the EuIII-CDTA system. These properties remain essentially the same in the pH range between 3.5 and 9. The most significant changes in the absorption spectra are observed above pH 10. In  the absorption spectra of EuIII-CDTA solutions at pH 7.40 and 11.0 have been juxtaposed. For both solutions two maxima at 17250 and 17239cm-1 may be observed for the 7F0 → 5D0 transition, which confirms the equilibrium of nine- and eight-coordinate isomers, as was previously reported at pH=6.0 . These values are similar both to the maximum found in the crystal at room temperature and to the analogous maxima found in solutions of the EuIII-EDTA complex (17254 and 17240cm-1) . There is another similarity that perhaps should be mentioned. Namely, the most intense crystal field components in the 7F0 → 5D2 transition in both solutions very closely match the analogous components in the spectrum of I at room temperature.

The most remarkable changes may be observed in the values of the oscillator strengths (). The P value of the transition 7F0 → 5D0 remains practically constant up to approximately pH=9 and then decreases by about half, reaching a value very similar to that calculated for I at room temperature. The magnetic-dipole allowed transition 7F0 → 5D1 in the solutions and in I at 293 K is constant with the P value close to the theoretical value . The intensity of the hypersensitive7F0 → 5D2 transition is, out of the three presented ones, the most affected by changes in the europium ion first coordination sphere. The oscillator strength of this band, like that of 7F0 → 5D0, does not change essentially up to pH~9, and then, contrary to the latter transition, doubles at pH=11. These changes may reflect the alterations within the first coordination sphere of the EuIII ion, consisting of partial substitution of coordinated water molecules by hydroxy anions  and/or formation of a polymeric species . The P values for the solutions are greater than in I at 293K, because of molecular dynamics around the metal ion in solutions.
